prior_works.title: Private and Continual Release of Statistics
prior_works.authors: T.-H. Hubert Chan; Elaine Shi; Dawn Song
prior_works.role: Foundational continual-observation mechanism (binary tree) for streaming counters
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the binary-tree aggregation technique that yields O(log T) noise for continual release, which the present paper generalizes from insertion-only counters to fully dynamic (turnstile) linear queries and uses as the timing/aggregation backbone of its black-box reduction.

prior_works.title: Differential Privacy Under Continual Observation
prior_works.authors: Cynthia Dwork; Moni Naor; Toniann Pitassi; Guy N. Rothblum
prior_works.role: Framework-setting work defining continual observation and hierarchical release
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the formal continual-observation model and hierarchical mechanisms that underlie the new reduction’s approach to releasing answers at every time step while controlling cumulative privacy loss.

prior_works.title: The Matrix Mechanism: Optimizing Linear Queries under Differential Privacy
prior_works.role: Canonical static mechanism for linear query workloads
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a high-accuracy static oracle for linear queries that the paper explicitly targets in its black-box reduction, showing how to lift such static mechanisms to fully dynamic streams with only polylogarithmic utility degradation.

prior_works.title: A Multiplicative Weights Mechanism for Privacy-Preserving Data Analysis
prior_works.role: General-purpose static linear query answering via MWEM
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Serves as a powerful static baseline that the paper’s black-box construction can wrap, demonstrating that adaptive static mechanisms like MWEM can be made to support continual, dynamic releases with bounded error blowup.

prior_works.title: On the Geometry of Differential Privacy
prior_works.role: Near-optimal static mechanisms for linear queries (K-norm/Gaussian mechanisms)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies geometric insights and mechanisms for static linear workloads that the new work can invoke as plug-in oracles, preserving (up to polylog factors) their near-optimal utility in the dynamic turnstile setting.

prior_works.title: The Johnson–Lindenstrauss Transform Itself Preserves Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Jeremiah Blocki; Avrim Blum; Anupam Datta; Or Sheffet
prior_works.role: Streaming-friendly, linear-sketch based static DP primitives
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how linear sketches that are easily maintainable under insertions and deletions can be made differentially private, a technical ingredient leveraged by the paper to maintain efficient dynamic state compatible with static DP oracles.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution is a black-box reduction that transforms high-accuracy static mechanisms for answering linear queries into mechanisms that support fully dynamic (turnstile) streams under continual observation, incurring only polylogarithmic utility loss. Two seminal strands of prior work directly converge here. First, continual-observation mechanisms—especially the binary-tree/hierarchical methods of Chan–Shi–Song and Dwork–Naor–Pitassi–Rothblum—established how to schedule noisy releases over time so that privacy composes gracefully while accuracy degrades only logarithmically in the horizon. These techniques provide the temporal aggregation scaffold that the present work extends from insertion-only counters to general linear queries with insertions and deletions.

Second, advances in static mechanisms for linear workloads—exemplified by the Matrix Mechanism, the multiplicative-weights mechanism (MWEM), and geometric/K-norm methods—yield near-optimal accuracy for static datasets. The new paper treats such mechanisms as black-box oracles, showing how to invoke them over carefully structured, disjoint summaries so that their static accuracy is preserved up to polylogarithmic factors in the dynamic setting.

Finally, streaming-friendly DP via linear sketches, as illustrated by the JL-based approach of Blocki–Blum–Datta–Sheffet, informs how to maintain compact, efficiently updatable representations under turnstile updates. Combining hierarchical time-partitioning with sketch-maintainable state enables efficient updates and continual releases. Together, these works directly enable the paper’s general transformation from static DP for linear queries to fully dynamic, continually released answers with provably small utility degradation.
